docs.snippet: LEAD: Rather than being concentrated in one area, Brooklyn's food shops are scattered about the borough like raisins in a Lenten hot-cross bun. Here is a sampling of some fairly recent newcomers to Brooklyn's eclectic gastronomic scene....

docs.snippet: LEAD: SINCE dawn, Taylor Dudley of Boston Beach, Jamaica, has been at work turning a pig and plenty of hot peppers into jerk, the island's devilishly hot answer to barbecue. At outdoor pits like Mr. Dudley's, roadside stands and restaurants throug...

byline.original: By KATHLEEN BECKETT-YOUNG; KATHLEEN BECKETT-YOUNG, a contributing editor of 7 Days, lives in New York

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: SINCE dawn, Taylor Dudley of Boston Beach, Jamaica, has been at work turning a pig and plenty of hot peppers into jerk, the island's devilishly hot answer to barbecue. At outdoor pits like Mr. Dudley's, roadside stands and restaurants throughout Jamaica, pork, plus chicken, conch and native fish are given the distinctive jerk treatment.

docs.snippet: NINTH AVENUE INTERNATIONAL, the Greek foods store right behind the Port Authority Bus Terminal, is filled with dazzling displays of nuts, legumes, grains, olives, spices, cheeses and olive oil at rock-bottom prices. The grocery selection is wonder...
docs.abstract: Comment on excellent taramosalata available at Ninth Avenue International, Greek grocery on Ninth Avenue behind Port Authority Bus Terminal; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: NINTH AVENUE INTERNATIONAL, the Greek foods store right behind the Port Authority Bus Terminal, is filled with dazzling displays of nuts, legumes, grains, olives, spices, cheeses and olive oil at rock-bottom prices. The grocery selection is wonderful -- no question -- but for an immediate goodness fix, head directly to the counter and ask for a container of taramosalata. Sam Karamouzis, the owner of the store and the creator of its dips, has acquired a cult following among both home cooks and professional chefs. Basing it on the traditional recipe, he has devised what the chef Rick Moonen calls ''the world's best taramosalata.'' Mr. Moonen, an owner of the highly regarded Greek restaurant Molyvos, in Manhattan, got his recipe for taramosalata from Mr. Karamouzis. The restaurant version is similar -- except in price. At Molyvos, an appetizer-size serving is $3.50. At the store, it's $4 a pound.

headline.main: Temptation; A Creamy Taramosalata, at a Store With a Fan Club

docs.snippet: The Physics of Noodles    Q. How are ''instant'' cereals, rice, and other foods processed to diminish cooking time?  A. It is really a physics problem involving the interaction of water with a carbohydrate, and the process differs from food to foo...
docs.abstract: Question & Answer column on the physics of making 'instant' foods like cereal and rice
docs.lead_paragraph: The Physics of Noodles Q. How are ''instant'' cereals, rice, and other foods processed to diminish cooking time? A. It is really a physics problem involving the interaction of water with a carbohydrate, and the process differs from food to food, said Dr. Joseph H. Hotchkiss, professor of food science at Cornell University.
